thread.title: Fortescue Metals Group 'open' to mine deal
thread.title_full: Fortescue Metals Group 'open' to mine deal | afr.com

author: James Thomson
title: Fortescue Metals Group 'open' to mine deal
text:
Fortescue chairman Andrew Forrest. Reuters Share on twitter by James Thomson Fortescue Metals Group says it is "open to commercial discussions" with potential investors in its mines and infrastructure, after its shares spiked on reports of a potential deal.
A report from Bloomberg suggested China's Hebei Iron & Steel Group and Tewoo Group had approached Fortescue Metals Group about acquiring a stake in the iron ore producer's infrastructure assets.
FMG's shares jumped by more than 9 per cent in early trade, and were up around 5.6 per cent to $1.87 in afternoon trade on Wednesday.
The miner released a statement on Wednesday afternoon responding to the speculation.
"As previously reported, whilst there is no imperative, Fortescue is open to commercial discussions with a range of groups on a regular basis at the mining asset level.
"There is no agreement of such nature with any party at this time."
Deals whereby miners sell stakes in their underlying mines and infrastructure assets are common in the iron ore sector - both BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto have such deals.
FMG, controlled by billionaire Andrew Forrest, said in March it would consider selling minority stakes in mines, railroads and ports .
 Iron ore prices have tumbled to the lowest since at least 2009 as the largest suppliers, including Rio and BHP, have expanded production despite economic growth in China slowing.
